body: Larry Elliott (Economics of Alice in Wonderland, 2 May) provides a test for Mr Cameron to do something to persuade people to support his EU stance: get Mrs Merkel and co to stop imposing more austerity on Greece – to show that the EU can equal mutual support – and we’ll vote to stay. Otherwise, what’s the point of the EU? The clock’s ticking, Dave.John BishopWolverhampton • Your leader on BHS (2 May) makes it clear that limited liability law is inadequate. In return for the privilege of limited liability, should not it be made illegal for a limited liability company to pay any dividends while the pension fund (holding employees’ deferred pay) is in deficit?David BarnardCholesbury, Buckinghamshire • Does Leicester really need Leicester City’s richly deserved triumph to put it on the map (Supplement, 4 May)? Aside from its other distinctions, Leicester also boasts other sporting achievement – Leicester Tigers have been rugby union champions of England 13 times (including three when a cup decided this) and twice of Europe. If rugby union’s besetting sin is smugness, football’s is myopia.Huw RichardsLondon • Michael Cunningham (Letters, 6 May) mentions Leicester band Family, which reminded me of seeing them in London in 2013, when they reformed for a couple of shows. They were introduced on stage by Leicester City legend Frank Worthington.Chris SimmondsAberdeen • I had never heard of modal verbs before reading the letters page (5 May). I went to a grammar school.Gerry MooreLondon  • Maybe the real reason for the English obsession with the Tudors (Tudormania, 4 May) is that they are among the minority of royals in English history who were actually English.Jan WiczkowskiManchester  • While it is sad to see it closing, even if New Day had only been published for a short while (Report, 5 May), any paper without a proper letters page is always going to struggle.Keith FlettLondon  • Join the debate – email guardian.letters@theguardian.com
